com.appittome.udacity.client
Class Udacity

java.lang.Object
  FragmentActivity
      com.appittome.udacity.client.Udacity
All Implemented Interfaces:
UserInterface.CredentialsDialog.OnNewCredentialsListener
public class Udacity
extends FragmentActivity
implements UserInterface.CredentialsDialog.OnNewCredentialsListener

Start here:: This is the Activity Class of the Application, most of the C from MVC is intended to end up here.

User Interface

The user design constists of 5 screens that appears as follows::
Sign In Course Selection Unit selection Video Selection Youtube video play

This class naturally attempts to organize much of the communication between the functional parts of application and the android OS. two main parts of the app require interaction with various parts of the android os:

User Interface requires access to the activity mainly to "inflate" XML resources to create new views that will then be linked back to the appropriate parent in the display graph. A seperate UI class (UserInterface) holds a set of utilites for the UI that access the activity through a subclass UdacityUserInterface that populates a set of abstract methods to access critical methods of the acivity, thereby limiting direct dependance and enabling modularity.

The second portion of the UI, the SwipeAdapter is a bit more conventional as it implements a FragmentStatePagerAdapter, that requires the activity (or context) as an argument.

This implementation is disjoint, but came about as a result of itteratively adding complexity.

Network Connection required access to a Network oriented Android services available only through the activity. The method of abstracting the necessary parts to be extended as a subclass of Udacity was used to allow similar benifits to the User Interface.

The third portion included here is intended to act as part of the model:

Credentials are included as an extended subclass neededing access between methods of the credentials, the connection (to test the credentials), and the UI (to request new credentials from the user). This does not really belong here and should at some time be removed.

The way it stands the progression though: checking credentials > possibly getting new credentials > checking credentials > fetch "account.courses_of_interest" > bouncing on the course path redirects > "course.get" is all asyncronous and rather impossible to stop once started as one thing often leads directly to the next. The next evolution should involve listeners (probably here for now, near the [controler/activity]) at each joint to allow more interesting control of the progression. In anycase, a progression usually consists of a static path through methods, and thereby new paths should be easily enough generated from subclasses of the Async classes in Connection (JSONPost, JSONGet, and grabPage) wherein onPostExecute can be implemented to the desired next turn.

promptForCredentials

public void promptForCredentials()
Build and show credentials dialog. When the dialog is closed it will notify a listener with the new credentials see UserInterface.CredentialsDialog

onNewCredentials

public void onNewCredentials(java.lang.String email,
                             java.lang.String pass)
onNewCredentials interface, called when UserInterface.CredentialsDialog returns. New user credentials from the UI usually mean that there were no previous credentials, or that the previous credentials failed on the server. The new credentials are set, and then a the connection is told to fetch a new cookie, which restarts the course populating waterfall.

Specified by:
onNewCredentials in interface UserInterface.CredentialsDialog.OnNewCredentialsListener
Parameters:
email - - new email credential
pass - -new password credential

onBackPressed

public void onBackPressed()
Back-crash-quick-fix. The back button causes the app to crash. attempting to pop something off the back stack - it finds nothing, and accidentally exits the app. When you restart, the app is in an unatural state, asks for login - finds a null pointer where there should be a fragment, and crashes. This implementation doesn't properly populate the backstack - but forces the app to close instead (which can be disorienting for the user).
